keyParams.title: Generative AI for professional tasks for the General Inspectorate of Education and Science (IGEC)
keyParams.description:
- **Main Goal**: This 3-day training develops IGEC staff's digital competences, enabling them to work confidently, responsibly, and efficiently with generative AI. Participants will progress from a foundational understanding of AI technology and governance to practical mastery of prompting techniques, RAG-based document analysis, and the creation of structured outputs for professional activities. A critical objective is to establish organisational capacity through the collaborative development of shared prompt libraries that ensure consistency across IGEC teams, capture expert methodologies, and support staff onboarding. Staff will enhance their capability to support schools in responsible AI adoption whilst developing critical awareness of appropriate use, limitations, ethical implications, and auditability requirements. The expected outcome is that IGEC will integrate AI-enhanced workflows into inspection practices whilst preserving professional judgement, transparency, and high standards of educational quality and integrity.
- **Delivery mode**: Days 1 and 2 are delivered in a hybrid format, whilst Day 3 is reserved for in-person collaborative work.
- The **methodology **integrates peer learning through group work, case study analysis, hands-on practice and reflection.

N.B.: The trainer is using a non-traditional approach: not a standard slide deck, but an HTML file that participants can browse independently (projected and distributed). They can share the full set of slides/outputs at the end of a webinar/session if required, even though the primary delivery format is not PowerPoint-based.
keyParams.toolsMaterials:

keyParams.name: Generative AI for professional tasks for the General Inspectorate of Education and Science (IGEC)
keyParams.targetAudience:
## Origin
- Participants are from the General Inspectorate of Education and Science (IGEC) accros across primary, secondary education and higher education.
- The group expects three participant profiles: 1) inspectors, 2) specialised staff participating in inspectorate activities (not formally inspectors), and 3) teachers on mobility/secondment within the organisation.

## Skills specificities
- Participants have varying digital competences and need to develop their competences to work responsibly and efficiently with generative AI.
keyParams.prerequisites:
- At least B1 (Intermediate) level in English.
- Basic familiarity with the Microsoft Office suite.
- Access credentials for MS 365 and especially Microsoft Copilot.
- Everyone must have a computer.

activities.title: Day 1 -  From Foundations to Governance: Establishing AI Literacy
activities.description:
- Establish a shared baseline in AI and generative AI (core concepts, capabilities, limitations).
- Introduce responsible-use and governance foundations (risk, accountability, privacy/data protection, transparency).
- Prepare participants for the hands-on work in Days 2–3 through shared language and expectations.
- Modality: blended (participants in person and online).

moments.title: 10:30-13:00 - AI Technology and Governance Frameworks
moments.description: Introduces core generative AI concepts (what it is, how it works, and the practical implications of its limits), then frames the main governance drivers (data protection, EU regulation, intellectual property, and accountability). The aim is a shared vocabulary and a realistic understanding of opportunities and risks before moving into competence development.

steps.title: Expectations (+ optional GenAI analysis of inputs)
steps.objective: Participants submit hopes, expectations, and questions via Wooclap (event code: IGEC26). The collected responses serve as a diagnostic baseline for the trainer and as a reference point to revisit at the close of the training. As an optional extension, the Wooclap outputs can be copied into Copilot for a live demonstration of GenAI text analysis, providing an early, low-stakes example of AI summarisation.
steps.presentation:
## Your expectations
1. Open Wooclap: [https://app.wooclap.com/IGEC26](https://app.wooclap.com/IGEC26) (event code: IGEC26 if prompted).
2. Share one or more hopes/expectations for the training and/or questions you want answered.
3. Save what you wrote — we’ll return to it at the end of the training.

steps.title: Presentation of the training plan
steps.objective: Provide participants with clear understanding of the training structure, learning progression, and expected outcomes.
steps.trainerTasks: Present the three-day arc: Day 1 (foundations and frameworks), Day 2 (practical application), Day 3 (creation and consolidation). Explain the pedagogical rationale for this progression. Demonstrate how to access and navigate the HTML presentation application. Highlight key milestones and deliverables. Explain how the training connects to DigComp frameworks and inspection practice.
steps.presentation:
## Main goal
- Develop IGEC staff's digital competences in working confidently, responsibly, and efficiently with generative AI for professional tasks.
---
## The journey
- Day 1: Foundations + Governance (legal and ethical) + AI-related competences
- Day 2: Promptig technics an creating agents 
- Day 3: Establish organisational capacity through the collaborative development of shared prompt libraries.
---
## Pedagogical approach
- Short inputs + activities + debrief
- Focus on transfer
- Materials: slides + reference links (where provided)
steps.notes: The HTML presentation approach is unconventional—frame it as modelling adaptive technology use. Emphasise that the trainer can update content in real-time based on participant needs. This introduction to the tool serves as the first implicit lesson in flexible AI-age pedagogy.
steps.evaluationSuivi: Verify that all participants can access the HTML file successfully. Note any questions that reveal misconceptions about training scope or approach.

steps.title: Presentation of the trainer
steps.objective: Brief self-introduction by the trainer, drawing on his background in philosophy teaching, teacher training, digital education policy at the Office of the Secretary-General of the European Schools, and contributions to European Commission expert groups on AI ethics in education and learning for sustainability. Keep this concise; the goal is to establish credibility and rapport, not deliver a full biography.
steps.presentation:
## Your trainer

With a background in teaching (philosophy, secondary level) and teacher training, François Jourde works at the [Office of the Secretary-General of the European Schools](https://www.eursc.eu/) (Brussels) in the fields of digital education and AI governance, learning for sustainability, professional development and Erasmus+ collaborations. He has contributed as an expert to the European Commission's working groups on AI Ethics in Education and on Learning for Sustainability.

Drawing upon a diverse professional trajectory that commenced with a foundational commitment to education, he brings a blend of pedagogical expertise and institutional experience to his current roles. This allows him to bridge the gap between classroom practice, institutional governance, and European policy.

- Work email: [francois.jourde@eursc.eu](mailto:francois.jourde@eursc.eu)
- [LinkedIn profile](https://www.linkedin.com/in/jourde/)

subMoments.title: Generative AI: Core concepts and capabilities

steps.title: AI definition - WordCloud
steps.objective: Collect keywords associated with AI in a word cloud. Debrief.
steps.tasks: Access Wooclap on their devices. Submit 2-3 keywords or phrases they associate with "Artificial Intelligence". View the emerging word cloud. Participate in whole-group discussion about patterns, misconceptions, and knowledge gaps revealed by the collective responses.
steps.trainerTasks: Launch Wooclap word cloud activity. Allow 2-3 minutes for submission. Display results prominently. Facilitate debrief by identifying: common themes, technical vs. popular culture associations, hopes and fears, knowledge gaps. Use this diagnostic information to calibrate subsequent explanations. Bridge from participants' existing mental models to more accurate technical understanding.
steps.presentation:
# What does ‘AI’ mean?
Let's build a **wordcloud**.
1. Open [wooclap.com](https://app.wooclap.com/IGEC26) (code: IGEC26)
2. Give your answer to: **One keyword for what AI is…**
steps.notes: This is a critical diagnostic moment. Expect a mixture of science fiction references, concerns about job displacement, and varying technical accuracy. Validate all contributions whilst gently correcting misconceptions. Use the word cloud as a reference point throughout Day 1, returning to evolve understanding. The visual, collaborative nature reduces anxiety about "correct" answers.
steps.evaluationSuivi: Diagnostic assessment of prior knowledge and attitudes towards AI. Document predominant themes for comparison at training conclusion. Identify participants who may need additional support or who have advanced knowledge.

steps.title: AI and GenAI definitions
steps.objective: Proposed definiton: A set of theories and techniques for developing computer systems (algorithmic data processing) capable of performing tasks typically associated with animal and human cognitive capacities.
steps.presentation:
## AI: simple definitions
- AI: computer systems that perform tasks (predictions, decisions, content creation) that would require cognitive abilities for animals and humans.
- GenAI: AI that can produce content (text, images, audio, code) based on patterns from training data (= a statistical tool: pattern-based generation)
---

## AI: advanced definitions
- Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a “*machine-based system that, for explicit or implicit objectives, infers, from theinput it receives, how to generate outputs such as predictions, content, recommendations, or decisions that can influence physical or virtual environments*” [OECD, 2024](https://doi.org/10.1787/623da898-en).
- “*AI system means a machine-based system that is designed to operate with varying levels of autonomy and that may exhibit adaptiveness after deployment, and that, for explicit orimplicit objectives, infers, from the input it receives, how to generate outputs such as predictions, content, recommendations, or decisions that can influence physical or virtual environments*” [EU AI Act, 2024](http://data.europa.eu/eli/reg/2024/1689/oj).

steps.title: AI typology
steps.objective: A brief overview of the main types of AI system (predictive models, classifiers, generative models, agentic systems), presented via a comparative table. Note that categories are not mutually exclusive and are intended as a practical orientation rather than a rigorous taxonomy. The goal is to help participants situate GenAI within the broader AI landscape and distinguish it from other systems they may encounter in educational contexts.
steps.presentation:
## Typology of AI systems
> Note: These categories are a practical overview, but they are not perfectly mutually exclusive (e.g., classifiers are a kind of predictive model; agentic systems typically combine multiple model types).

| **AI System Type**            | **Function**                                | **How It Uses Data**                                                                 | **Example**                                      |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Classifier**               | Assigns labels to inputs                    | Learns patterns that separate categories                                             | Email spam filter                                 |
| **Regressor / Forecaster**   | Predicts a number or future value(s)        | Learns relationships and trends from historical data                                 | Predicting credit risk score; demand forecasting |
| **Recommender / Ranker**     | Suggests or orders items                    | Learns from user behaviour plus item/content and context signals                     | Netflix recommendations                           |
| **Generative model**         | Produces new content (text, images, etc.)   | Learns representations/statistical structure of data to generate plausible outputs   | ChatGPT; image generators                         |
| **Agentic / autonomous system** | Plans and acts towards goals             | Uses models plus feedback from an environment; may call tools and update state over time | Navigation robot; tool-using assistant        |
---
##  AI isn’t a tool – it’s an agent
> "AI is the first technology in history that can make decisions and create new ideas by itself. All previous human inventions [...] are dumb tools, lacking the intelligence necessary to process information and make independent decisions. In contrast, AI can process information by itself, and thereby replace humans in decision-making. **AI isn’t a tool – it’s an agent**."
> Harari, Y. N. (2024). *NEXUS: A Brief History of Information Networks from the Stone Age to AI.* Signal.
---
## AI = general-purpose technology (omni-use)
> A General Purpose Technology is a technology that has the potential to profoundly affect a wide range of industries, transform societies, and spur further innovations: steam engine, electricity, information technology.

steps.title: AI - Historical overview & AI approaches
steps.objective:
- Develop a foundational understanding of AI evolution, enabling participants to contextualise current GenAI capabilities within broader AI history/
- Appreciate why LLMs function probabilistically rather than logically.
- Present a concise historical overview: symbolic AI (1950s-1980s) based on explicit rules and logic; connectionist AI (resurgence from 2010s) based on pattern recognition and learning from data. Use concrete examples: symbolic = chess programmes with programmed strategies; connectionist = image recognition learning from millions of examples. Explain why the connectionist approach enabled the current GenAI revolution. Connect to inspection context: rules-based evaluation criteria vs. pattern recognition in pupil work.
steps.presentation:
## At the origin of “AI”
- **Common challenge**: imitate or simulate cognitive activities using algorithmic machines.
- **A (contested) presupposition**: intelligence can be modelled as mathematical operations that are, in principle, substrate-independent (i.e., they could occur in living bodies or in digital media):
  - Thinking or learning is equivalent to calculating (a computationalist thesis).
  - These calculations can be formalised logically (or mathematically) as algorithms.
  - These algorithms can be executed by digital machines.
  - These machines can therefore be attributed (at least operationally) with intelligence, learning, or thought.
---
## Approaches to algorithms in AI
- **Symbolic AI:** represents knowledge explicitly (symbols, rules, logic, ontologies) and solves problems via reasoning procedures. Rules/knowledge are primarily specified by humans.
- **Connectionist AI:** models cognition using networks of weighted units (neural networks) and mathematical functions; behaviour is learned via optimisation (e.g., gradient descent), typically from data.
- **Data-driven AI:** learns patterns/statistical regularities from datasets to make predictions or generate outputs; humans shape behaviour through dataset design/curation, labelling, objective functions, and post-training methods (e.g., fine-tuning, RLHF). Often—but not exclusively—implemented with connectionist models.
---

## Three magic ingredients of today's AI
Why is it working now when it failed before?
1. **Mountains of data**: the internet has given us more text, images and videos than humanity has produced in its entire history
2. **Phenomenal computing power**: graphics processing units (GPUs), originally created for video games, are proving to be perfect for AI
3. **Brilliant algorithms**: notably "transformers" (2017), which enable AI to understand context like never before
![](https://github.com/jourde/GenAI-training-IGEC/blob/main/images/3-ingredients-AI.png?raw=true)
steps.notes: Keep this historical framing brief—it's context, not the core content.
steps.evaluationSuivi: Check understanding through quick verbal checks or show-of-hands questions: "Which approach is more like how humans actually learn?" Monitor for glazed expressions indicating information overload.

steps.title: The Arrival of LLM-based GenAI: A conversational transmutation tool
steps.objective:
- Introduce LLM-based GenAI as fundamentally a tool for conversational transformation of inputs into outputs.
- Emphasise the "conversational" aspect—iterative refinement through dialogue. Highlight both power and limitations: excellent at patterns and transformations, but not truly "intelligent" or reliable for factual accuracy without verification.

- The "transmutation" framing helps participants see GenAI as a tool, not a thinking entity.
- Acknowledge the anthropomorphising tendency ("it thinks," "it knows") and gently correct towards more accurate language ("it predicts," "it generates patterns").
steps.presentation:
## What changed with LLM-based GenAI?
- General-purpose generation across domains
- Natural-language interface (conversational ‘command line’)
- Rapid adoption via mainstream tools
---
## A conversational transmutation tool
> "one of the most valuable aspects of LLMs is in information transmutation. [Siemens, 2025](https://buttondown.com/SAIL/archive/sail-transmutation-assessment-robots/)
↓
↓
![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/An_alchemist_in_his_laboratory._Wellcome_L0076242.jpg/960px-An_alchemist_in_his_laboratory._Wellcome_L0076242.jpg?20141022080757)
[image](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:An_alchemist_in_his_laboratory._Wellcome_L0076242.jpg)
steps.notes:
- Engage with the concept of GenAI as a "conversational transmutation tool".
- Consider the transformation capabilities: text-to-text, text-to-image, text-to-code, etc.
- Reflect on which transformations might be most relevant to participant work.
- Ask questions about capabilities and limitations.
steps.evaluationSuivi: Assess comprehension through observation of reactions to live demonstrations. Note which functionalities generate most interest or scepticism—this indicates relevance to participants' needs.

steps.title: Transformer explainer visualisation
steps.objective:
Visualise an LLM in action (GPT-2) poloclub.github.io: https://poloclub.github.io/transformer-explainer/
- Observe how the model predicts the next word based on patterns in training data.
- Discuss observations: What surprises them? What confirms their understanding? What remains mysterious?

- Explain key concepts: tokens, attention mechanisms, probability-based selection.
- Emphasise that the model has no "understanding"—it's sophisticated pattern-matching. -> Connect to previous content: this is connectionist AI visualised.
- Keep technical explanation accessible; focus on building intuition rather than deep technical knowledge.
steps.presentation:
# LLMs = prediction engines
- Core behaviour: predict the next token given context
- Outputs are probabilistic (≠ deterministic reasoning)
- Key unit: token (≈word pieces)
---
# Interactive explainer
 ➜ [transformer-explainer](https://poloclub.github.io/transformer-explainer/)
- **Context window**: what the model can ‘see’ at once
- **Probability distribution** over candidate tokens
- **Temperature / randomness**: variability vs stability
steps.notes: This visualisation is powerful for demystifying AI—it makes the "black box" transparent. However, it can be overwhelming. Frame it as: "You don't need to understand every detail, but seeing inside helps you understand why GenAI sometimes produces unexpected results." The key takeaway: LLMs predict based on patterns, not meaning. This explains both their power (pattern recognition across vast data) and limitations (no true comprehension, potential for plausible-sounding nonsense). Allow silence for absorption—this is cognitively demanding content.
steps.evaluationSuivi: Monitor engagement with the visualisation. Note questions or comments that reveal understanding or confusion about probabilistic nature of LLMs. Assess whether participants grasp the non-deterministic, statistical nature of generation.

steps.title: LLM training stages and machenery ("factory floor")
steps.objective: Demystify how LLMs are created, helping participants understand the "factory floor" of AI production and its implications for capabilities, biases, and limitations.
steps.presentation:
## How LLMs are made: three-stage training process
- Pre-training = immersive language learning from reading millions of books.
- Fine-tuning = specialised training for specific professions;
- RLHF = learning from feedback on what constitutes helpful vs. unhelpful responses.
⚠️ Human labour involved: data curation, annotation, feedback.

### Some infographics
![](https://i0.wp.com/leonfurze.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/AI-Iceberg-full.png?resize=2048%2C1152&ssl=1)
[source](https://leonfurze.com/2023/05/18/the-ai-iceberg-understanding-chatgpt/)
![](https://www.concentrix.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/blog-pull-quote-evolution-of-ai-timeline-1.webp)
[source](https://www.concentrix.com/insights/blog/a-guide-to-the-evolution-of-ai/)
![](https://www.armand.so/content/images/2023/11/WhatsApp-Image-2023-11-17-at-5.01.10-PM.jpeg)
[source](https://www.armand.so/the-history-of-ai/)
---
## Where Risks Enter
- Training data: bias, toxicity, copyrighted content
- Deployment: privacy leakage
- Optimisation: ‘helpfulness’ vs truthfulness trade-offs
---
## What This Means for Practice
- Ask: What model? What data? What safeguards?
- Document: purpose, risks, mitigations, monitoring
- Prefer tools with clear governance + transparency
steps.notes: This "behind the scenes" view is crucial for critical AI literacy. Participants should understand that LLMs are products of specific choices about data, methods, and values—not neutral or objective. This foundation supports later discussions of bias, reliability, and appropriate use cases. Use the manufacturing metaphor consistently: these are engineered products with design limitations. For school inspectors, this parallels their understanding that assessment tools reflect particular values and priorities.
steps.evaluationSuivi: Check understanding through questioning: "Why might an LLM trained primarily on English-language internet content have different knowledge about Portuguese education policies?" Assess whether participants grasp the connection between training process and model behaviour.

steps.title: Environmental aspects
steps.objective: Digital sobriety: The environmental impact of digital technology in general, and AI in particular, calls for vigilance in terms of sustainable development. The use of AI should be part of a digital sobriety approach: the aim is to avoid dependence on AI tools and to raise awareness among stakeholders of the energy costs associated with certain algorithmic processes.
steps.presentation:
## Environmental footprint: Where it comes from
- Training (large compute) vs inference (everyday use)
- Data centres: energy mix, cooling, hardware lifecycle
- Efficiency varies widely by model and usage pattern
---
## Mitigation Levers (Practical)
- Use ‘right-sized’ models for the task
- Short prompts; reuse context; avoid unnecessary regeneration
- Prefer providers with credible energy/efficiency reporting

steps.title: Main models
steps.objective: A brief orientation to the current landscape of leading GenAI models, using the Arena.ai leaderboard as a live reference. The aim is to give participants a realistic sense of the diversity of available tools — beyond Copilot — and to contextualise the choice of Microsoft Copilot as the institutional tool for this training. Keep this overview light; it will evolve rapidly and the leaderboard is the most reliable up-to-date source.
steps.presentation: -> [Arena.ai: Leaderboard Overview](https://arena.ai/fr/leaderboard): See how leading models stack up across text, image, vision, and beyond.

steps.title: Break
steps.objective: Twenty-minute break. No trainer action required beyond announcing the return time and signalling what comes next (governance frameworks).
steps.presentation:
# ☕️ Break: 20 minutes

## During this break:
- Refresh and recharge
- Reflect on legal/governance frameworks covered
- Network with colleagues
- Prepare questions for upcoming sessions

### Coming up next:
→ More on legal requirements and competence frameworks

subMoments.title: Navigating AI Governance: Legal, Ethical and Regulatory Landscapes

steps.title: AI as a disruption
steps.objective: Introduces the concept of technological disruption as an industrial strategy that bypasses established social rules and institutions, contextualising the rapid expansion of AI tools in public and educational sectors. This framing helps participants understand why governance frameworks are reactive and still evolving, and why professional judgement remains essential. Keep the tone analytical rather than alarmist.
steps.presentation:
## AI as a disruption
- Disruption refers to an industrial strategy that involves imposing disruptive technological innovations by bypassing social and local rules and institutions.
- For the past thirty years or so, disruptive strategy has enabled digital industries to establish themselves by bypassing laws and institutions, speeding up the adoption process.
.
> "In contrast to adopted technologies, “**arrival technologies**” bypass the planning, assessment, policy-making, and professional learning that have historically (if imperfectly) accompanied previous generations of technology integration .Some prior innovations could be classified, at least partially, as arrival technologies – students brought their personal calculators to math class in the 20th century; mobile phones brought the internet into some classrooms before intentional adoption – but **generative AI represents a step change in both the velocity and nature of technology arrival**." [Justin Reich, 2024](https://clalliance.org/blog/gptd-on-arrival-a-new-paradigm-for-understanding-education-technologies/)

steps.title: GDPR
steps.objective: - Understand GDPR implications for AI use at work, particularly regarding personal data processing, data subject rights, and lawful bases for automated decision-making in educational contexts
steps.presentation:
## GDPR essentials
- **Lawfulness, fairness and transparency**: Have a valid legal basis, treat people fairly, and explain clearly what you do with their data.
- **Purpose limitation**: Collect data for specific, explicit purposes and don’t reuse it for incompatible ones.
- **Data minimisatio**n: Only collect what is necessary for the stated purpose.
- **Accuracy**: Keep data accurate and up to date; correct or delete inaccuracies promptly.
- **Storage limitation**: Keep data only as long as it is needed for the purpose (then delete or anonymise).
- **Integrity and confidentiality (security)**: Protect data with appropriate technical and organisational measures.
- **Accountability**: Be able to demonstrate compliance (records, policies, training, and evidence).
---

## GDPR essentials for GenAI use
- Personal data: any identifiable person (direct/indirect)
- Key principles: lawfulness, fairness, transparency, purpose limitation, data minimisation, security, automated decision.
- Roles: controller vs processor (and responsibilities)
---
## High-Risk moments in GenAI use
- **Pupil/staff data pasted into prompts** -> Any introduction of personal data into an AI system (e.g., entering data into a prompt, enhancing a photo using AI) constitutes a processing operation that must comply with the GDPR.
- **Uncontrolled retention** (chat history, training on inputs)
- **Non-approved** third-party tools, and with unclear processing/location -> Processing data with Microsoft Copilot (enterprise-grade, GDPR-compliant) versus public GenAI tools.

steps.title: EU AI Act
steps.objective: Understand the EU AI Act's risk-based classification system and its implications for AI use in educational inspection, particularly regarding high-risk applications in education and prohibited practices.
steps.presentation:
## EU AI Act: core logic
- **Risk-based approach**: unacceptable / high / limited / minimal
- **Obligations increase with risk and role** (provider/deployer)
- Focus: **safety, fundamental rights, transparency**
.
![](https://i0.wp.com/epthinktank.eu/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/artificial-intelligence.png?ssl=1&fit=3840%2C1694)

### Obligations relevant to inspectors
- transparency and documentation
- human oversight
- accountability
steps.notes: Keep this practical: inspectors need a usable mental model and a short checklist, not legal detail. Use one scenario (e.g., pupil profiling, automated recommendation, or surveillance-like uses) to anchor risk classification.

steps.title: Intellectual Property
steps.objective:
Understand intellectual property considerations in GenAI use, including copyright in AI-generated content, use of copyrighted materials in prompts, and professional obligations regarding content attribution in inspection documentation.
Respect for copyright: AI operates on pre-existing content, which it uses to train. However, this content may be protected by copyright. The use of AI-generated or AI-exploited content must comply with this right. It is therefore necessary to be cautious and only insert authorised content into AI, otherwise there is a risk of being prosecuted for copyright infringement. Preference should therefore be given to content that is not protected by copyright, or that has fallen into the public domain, or that is authorised for use under a licence.
steps.tasks: Consider IP scenarios: If GenAI generates inspection report text, who owns the copyright? Can inspectors use copyrighted educational materials in their prompts? What about pupil work samples? Understand that AI-generated content may not be copyrightable in all jurisdictions. Recognise obligations to disclose AI use in official documentation. Discuss implications for inspection reports that may be published or shared publicly.
steps.trainerTasks: Present current legal understanding of GenAI and IP (noting ongoing legal evolution). Key points: AI-generated content copyright is contested and jurisdiction-dependent; using copyrighted materials in prompts may constitute fair use/dealing depending on purpose; Portuguese public sector documentation requirements regarding AI use. Provide practical guidance: Always review and substantially modify AI-generated content before official use; maintain human authorship and accountability; disclose AI assistance in appropriate contexts; respect copyright in materials uploaded to AI tools. Emphasise that inspectors remain legally responsible for all content they publish, regardless of AI involvement.
steps.presentation:
## IP + GenAI: The Basics
- Copyright protects original expression (not ideas)
- Training-data and output questions vary by jurisdiction
- GenAI output = no copyright: AI lacks legal personhood, so its outputs may not be eligible for copyright protection.
---
## Common Risk Scenarios
- Using copyrighted text/images as prompt inputs without rights
- Generating ‘in the style of’ a living creator for publication
- Reusing outputs without checking similarity to known works
---
## Practical Guidance
- Prefer licensed/open resources; keep evidence of licences
- Avoid prompts that request verbatim reproduction
- When publishing: attribute + document tool/use where required

steps.title: How to give credit to GenAI?
steps.objective: Present current legal understanding of GenAI and IP (noting ongoing legal evolution). Key points: AI-generated content copyright is contested and jurisdiction-dependent; using copyrighted materials in prompts may constitute fair use/dealing depending on purpose; Portuguese public sector documentation requirements regarding AI use. Provide practical guidance: Always review and substantially modify AI-generated content before official use; maintain human authorship and accountability; disclose AI assistance in appropriate contexts; respect copyright in materials uploaded to AI tools. Emphasise that inspectors remain legally responsible for all content they publish, regardless of AI involvement.
steps.tasks: Explore different citation models for AI use: in-text acknowledgement (\"This section was developed with assistance from Microsoft Copilot\"), footnotes, methodology statements in appendices. Consider where in inspection documentation AI use should be disclosed: in the report itself? In internal documentation? In methodological notes? Practise writing clear, concise AI acknowledgement statements. Discuss: How much detail is appropriate? When is disclosure required vs. optional?
steps.trainerTasks: Present emerging professional practices for AI citation, drawing from academic, governmental, and professional standards. Provide templates for different contexts: formal inspection reports, internal working documents, published analyses. Key principle: transparency about substantial AI assistance whilst maintaining professional credibility and readability. Guidance: Disclose when AI has generated significant text or analysis; acknowledge AI as a tool (like statistical software) rather than a co-author; focus on professional accountability (the inspector validates and takes responsibility for all content). Provide IGEC-specific recommendations if institutional policy exists. Emphasise that evolving practices will develop as professional norms emerge.
steps.presentation:
## Why Credit Matters
- Academic integrity and transparency
- Accountability: what was human-authored vs AI-assisted
- Traceability for review, appeal, and improvement
---
## A Simple Declaration Template
- Tool(s) used: [name + version if known]
- Purpose: [drafting / summarising / translating / ideation]
- Human actions: [edited, verified, added sources]
---
## What to Keep (Lightweight Audit Trail)
- Prompt + key context (no personal data)
- Final output + what was changed
- Date/time + user responsible (where appropriate)
steps.notes:
Make the presentation tangible by showing 2–3 ready-to-reuse disclosure examples:
- short in-text acknowledgement,
- footnote format,
- “methodological note” paragraph for inspection reports.
Explicitly distinguish between internal working notes vs published outputs. End with a quick “which is appropriate here?” micro-quiz (3 scenarios, hands up).

moments.title: 14:00-17:30 - Developing Professional AI Competences

subMoments.title: From “AI as a Tool” to “AI as a Partner”: Delegation, Augmentation, Transformation

steps.title: GenAI and Human Skills
steps.objective: Draws on the OECD AI Capability Indicators framework to examine how AI capabilities compare to human abilities, identifying areas where humans remain superior and where the risk of over-reliance (the "mirage of false mastery") is greatest. Introduces the concept of hybrid human–AI competence and the importance of maintaining metacognitive skills alongside AI use. Reference Molenaar (2022, 2024) if participants wish to explore the research base further.
steps.presentation:
## AI competences and human competences
OECD, [https://aicapabilityindicators.oecd.org](https://aicapabilityindicators.oecd.org).
- Framework for monitoring AI capabilities in relation to human abilities.
- Enables the identification of areas in which humans remain superior and that merit priority educational investment.
---
## Some concerns
- **Cognitive offloading** and **de-skilling**: research has begun to quantify the **risks associated with reduced human cognition and metacognition** in contexts of intensive AI use.
- “**mirage of false mastery**”: the impressive outputs generated by AI mask the underdevelopment of essential skills, including hybrid human-AI skills (OECD. Digital Education Outlook 2026: Effective Uses of Generative AI in Education)
steps.notes:
To be explored: paradigm of hybrid human-AI collaboration (Molenaar, 2022, 2024).
- Molenaar, I. (2022). The concept of hybrid human-AI regulation: Exemplifying how to support young learners' self-regulated learning. Computers and Education: Artificial Intelligence, 3, 100070. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.caeai.2022.100070 
Molenaar, I. (2022). Towards hybrid human‐AI learning technologies. European Journal of Education, 57/4, pp. 632-645. https://doi.org/10.1111/ejed.12527 
- Molenaar, I. (2024). Human-AI collaboration in education: The hybrid future. Inaugural Speech RU. Radboud University, Nijmegen. https://hdl.handle.net/2066/316067

- OECD. (2026). Digital Education Outlook 2026: Effective Uses of Generative AI in Education. OECD Publishing:
  - Recent empirical research has begun to quantify the risks associated with reduced human cognition and metacognition in contexts of intensive AI use (OECD, 2026, p. 52).
  - the “mirage of false mastery”, whereby the impressive outputs generated by AI mask the underdevelopment of essential skills, including hybrid human-AI skills (OECD, 2026, p. 57).

steps.title: Delegation - augmentation - tranformation
steps.objective: Understand delegation (substitution), collaboration (assistance), and transformation (amplification) paradigms of AI-human interaction. Explore the three paradigms of AI-human interaction and discuss implications for professional practices.
steps.presentation:
## Three ways to use GenAI | GenAI as a… | GenAI role | Gain | Risk | |---|---|---|---| | **prosthesis** | substitution | immediate comfort (cognitive offloading) | technological dependency/submission; skill decay | | **orthosis** | collaboration | skill reinforcement; co-intelligence | … | | **auxesis** | radical amplification | multiplier of human capabilities, enabling the user to achieve results they could never have imagined obtaining on their own, even with traditional resources; GenAI can transcend structural limits of human cognition by processing volumes of parameters/data and complexities otherwise inaccessible | … |
N.B.: - A **prosthesis** replaces a failing or missing function. - An **orthosis** supports and improves an existing function. - An **auxesis** (gr. *auxēsis*: "growth" or "increase") amplifies or increases an existing capacity without substituting for, or correcting, a function. Adapted from [Las Vergnas, O., Jeunesse, C. et Adinda, D. (2025). De la délégation à l’amplification : quand l’IA générative reconfigure nos façons d’apprendre. Action publique. Recherche et pratiques, 25(2), 23-36.](https://shs.cairn.info/revue-action-publique-recherche-et-pratiques-2025-2-page-23).
steps.notes:
To be explored: paradigm of hybrid human-AI collaboration (Molenaar, 2022, 2024).
- Molenaar, I. (2022). The concept of hybrid human-AI regulation: Exemplifying how to support young learners' self-regulated learning. Computers and Education: Artificial Intelligence, 3, 100070. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.caeai.2022.100070 
Molenaar, I. (2022). Towards hybrid human‐AI learning technologies. European Journal of Education, 57/4, pp. 632-645. https://doi.org/10.1111/ejed.12527 
- Molenaar, I. (2024). Human-AI collaboration in education: The hybrid future. Inaugural Speech RU. Radboud University, Nijmegen. https://hdl.handle.net/2066/316067

- OECD. (2026). Digital Education Outlook 2026: Effective Uses of Generative AI in Education. OECD Publishing:
  - Recent empirical research has begun to quantify the risks associated with reduced human cognition and metacognition in contexts of intensive AI use (OECD, 2026, p. 52).
  - the “mirage of false mastery”, whereby the impressive outputs generated by AI mask the underdevelopment of essential skills, including hybrid human-AI skills (OECD, 2026, p. 57).

steps.title: Example: Framework for the use of GenAI in the European Schools
steps.objective: Analyse a concrete governance framework example and extract transferable elements for Portuguese inspection practice (principles, safeguards, and implementation conditions).
steps.tasks:
Follow the short presentation, then identify:
1) two “non-negotiables” (e.g., data protection, transparency),
2) one implementation risk (e.g., unequal access, staff capability),
3) one element that could transfer to inspection guidance.
Share one point in plenary.
steps.trainerTasks: Present the framework in 10 minutes using 3–5 slides: purpose, scope, core principles, safeguards, and implementation supports. Then facilitate a 5-minute plenary share-out (3–4 contributions) and capture transferable elements.
steps.presentation:
# Example Policy Framework: Core Blocks
- Purpose & scope (what is allowed, for whom, where)
- Data protection (GDPR), security, and vendor requirements
- Ethics: fairness, transparency, inclusion, wellbeing
---
# Operational Controls
- Approved tools + review cycle
- Role-based guidance (leaders, teachers, support staff)
- Training & support; incident reporting; monitoring
---
# Implementation Steps
- 1) Baseline: current use + risks
- 2) Draft policy + consult stakeholders
- 3) Pilot + evaluate; then scale with evidence
steps.notes: Position this as “a worked example”: the goal is not to adopt it wholesale but to extract a reusable structure for governance and inspection criteria.

steps.title: DigComp 3.0: Presentation
steps.objective: General understanding of DigComp 3.0 structure and AI competence integration.
steps.presentation:
## DigComp 3.0 (European Commission)
[DigComp3.0](https://joint-research-centre.ec.europa.eu/projects-and-activities/education-and-training/digital-transformation-education/digital-competence-framework-digcomp/digcomp-30_en)
- EU digital competence reference framework (latest version)
- Technology-neutral
- Can be used for policy, assessment, training design...

### Policy context
- DigComp 3.0 embodies the principles of the [European Declaration on Digital Rights and Principles for the Digital Decade](https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=OJ:JOC_2023_023_R_0001), which **puts people at the centre of the digital transformation** and helps to ground the framework in a set of **shared European values and principles**.
- It also aligns with **European policies and initiatives related to digital skills and the societal impacts of the digital transformation**, such as the [Digital Decade policy programme](https://digital-strategy.ec.europa.eu/en/policies/digital-decade-policy-programme), the [Union of Skills](https://commission.europa.eu/topics/eu-competitiveness/union-skills_en), the [European Pillar of Social Rights Action Plan](https://op.europa.eu/webpub/empl/european-pillar-of-social-rights/en/), and the [European Strategy for a Better Internet for Kids](https://digital-strategy.ec.europa.eu/en/policies/strategy-better-internet-kids) (BIK+).
- The framework acknowledges the **rights and responsibilities of citizens under EU regulations** such as the [General Data Protection Regulation](https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/policies/data-protection-regulation/), the [Digital Services Act](https://commission.europa.eu/strategy-and-policy/priorities-2019-2024/europe-fit-digital-age/digital-services-act_en), the [Digital Markets Act](https://digital-markets-act.ec.europa.eu/about-dma_en) and the [AI Act](https://digital-strategy.ec.europa.eu/en/policies/regulatory-framework-ai).
---

## Five Competence Areas
![](https://joint-research-centre.ec.europa.eu/sites/default/files/2025-11/DigCompFrameworkChartExpl.png)
---

## The update integrates five major themes
•   Artificial Intelligence (including generative AI) competence
•   Cybersecurity and safety competence
•   Digital rights, choice and responsibilities
•   Wellbeing and inclusion in digital environments
•   Competence to tackle misinformation and disinformation.
---

## How to read a competence
![](https://joint-research-centre.ec.europa.eu/sites/default/files/styles/embed_large/public/2025-11/Figure_web_competence_area.png?itok=pqTNvkWv)

- The **content** aspect of the framework is organised hierarchically – **learning outcomes** and **competence statements** are grouped under the **21 competences**, and the 21 competences are grouped under the **five competence areas**.
- The **progression** aspect of the framework is described in the **four proficiency levels** (Basic, Intermediate, Advanced and Highly advanced). DigComp includes a general **definition** of each of these levels, which are **illustrated** in a concrete way in the competence statements and the learning outcomes.
- **AI competence integration** is present in all levels of the content aspect of the framework, and AI competence is present in all 21 competences. At the more detailed content levels, individual competence statements and learning outcomes, **AI labelling** is used to show where AI competence features in the framework.
[image](https://joint-research-centre.ec.europa.eu/projects-and-activities/education-and-training/digital-transformation-education/digital-competence-framework-digcomp/digcomp-30_en)
---
## How to read DigComp 3.0
![](https://github.com/jourde/DigComp-3.0/blob/main/images/png/page%2030.png?raw=true)
---

## Example
![](https://github.com/jourde/DigComp-3.0/blob/main/images/png/page%2047.png?raw=true)

---

## 👍 DigComp 3.0 resources
[DigComp 3.0 resources](https://joint-research-centre.ec.europa.eu/projects-and-activities/education-and-training/digital-transformation-education/digital-competence-framework-digcomp/digcomp-30-resources_en): DigComp 3.0 framework in PDF, editable, spreadsheet and structured data formats, and with guidelines on using, adapting and re-publishing them.

steps.title: DigComp 3.0: Activity

steps.presentation:
## Mapping exercise (groups → plenary)
(1) Open the [exercice page](https://jourde.github.io/GenAI-training-IGEC/activities/digcomp_mapping.html) and the DigComp 3.0 (full framework): [link](https://joint-research-centre.ec.europa.eu/projects-and-activities/education-and-training/digital-transformation-education/digital-competence-framework-digcomp/digcomp-30_en)

(2) In groups, choose at least **one concrete professional task** where GenAI could be used (e.g., drafting a note, analysing evidence, synthesising stakeholder input).

(3) For each task, identify **at least one competence** you would need to strengthen.  Use the interface to:
- Write the chosen **task**.
- Select the **competence** (area + competence)
- Select the **required proficiency level**
- Write a **brief justification** (“why this competence matters for the task”)

(4) Copy the generated **summary** and paste it into the [online MS Form](https://forms.office.com/e/R57bxJUZXX).

(5) Be ready to share **a competence mapping** in plenary.

General understanding of the AI Litteracy Framework:

During the guided walkthrough, note:

steps.presentation:
## AILit Framework (EC & OECD)
[https://ailiteracyframework.org/](https://ailiteracyframework.org/)
---

## Definition of AI Literacy
> AI literacy represents the technical knowledge, durable skills, and future-ready attitudes required to thrive in a world influenced by AI. It enables learners to engage, create with, manage, and design AI, while critically evaluating its benefits, risks, and ethical implications.
---

## Relationship to Other Topics and Disciplines
![](https://github.com/jourde/IGEC/blob/main/images/AIlitteracy_relationship.png?raw=true)
---

## Four domains of AI literacy
= different ways in which learners interact with AI, encompassing 22 competences.
.
![](https://github.com/jourde/IGEC/blob/main/images/AI-competences.png?raw=true)
.
![](https://github.com/jourde/IGEC/blob/main/images/fourdpomainsofAIlitteracy.jpg?raw=true)
--
- **Engaging with AI** involves using AI as a tool to access new content,information, or recommendations. These situations require learners to first recognize AI’s presence, then evaluate the accuracy and relevance of AI outputs. Learners must develop a fundamental understanding of AI’s technicalfoundations in order to critically analyze its capabilities and limitations.
- **Creating with AI** consists of collaborating with an AI system in acreative or problem-solving process. It involves guiding and refining AI output through prompts and feedback, while ensuring the content remains fairand appropriate. It also involves ethical considerations related to contentownership, attribution, and the responsible use of existing materials.
- **Managing AI** requires intentionally choosing how AI can support andenhance human work. This includes assigning structured tasks to AI, such as organizing information, so humans can focus on areas requiring creativity,empathy, and judgment. AI systems can simulate a variety of roles, acting asan analyst, debate partner, or career guide. Learners who manage AI’s actions learn to delegate tasks thoughtfully, guide AI outputs with clear instructions,and assess whether AI’s role aligns with their goals and values. This domainhelps learners build agency, ensuring that AI works for them and that its useremains ethical and human-centered.
- **Designing AI** empowers learners to understand how AI works andconnect it to its social and ethical impacts by shaping how AI systems function. Through hands-on exploration in an education context, students examine howdata, design choices, and model behavior influence the fairness, usefulness, and impact of AI systems. The goal is not to develop commercial products orput them into service, but to build the confidence and capacity to shape AI for human good by understanding the principles underpinning the design of AI from an early age.
---
## Anatomy of a competence
![](https://github.com/jourde/GenAI-training-IGEC/blob/main/images/anatomy_of_a_competence.png?raw=true)
steps.notes: Avoid “framework overload”. Make the presentation selective: prioritise what changes inspection practice (evidence, criteria, and guidance), not exhaustive coverage.

steps.presentation:
## Guided tour - Open [https://m365.cloud.microsoft](https://m365.cloud.microsoft/). - Follow the guide!
-> You can also always refer to the Microsoft guidance: [learn.microsoft.com/pt-pt/copilot](https://learn.microsoft.com/pt-pt/copilot/) --- ## Keyboard shortcuts to use: - Use / to mention a person, file, or object to bring it into context - Use @ to mention an agent - Three dots (…) in top-right corner to access Copilot memory setting
steps.notes: - "Microsoft Copilot is still something of a sticking point: it is marketed into schools as “safe and private“, but it is really just another product built on top of OpenAI’s GPT model. Frustratingly, it’s not even as good as ChatGPT: anyone who has used Copilot on the web will know that the product is far behind other leading models. Essentially, forcing staff to use Copilot is unlikely to work for anyone trying to get the most out of GenAI, and it’s highly likely that they’ll instead turn to ChatGPT, Claude and Gemini and just not tell anyone." Leon Furze https://read.readwise.io/read/01kffsqwcd70f4e956wjaj7724

steps.title: Prompt: definition
steps.objective: Introduces the working definition of a prompt as a natural-language instruction that directs a GenAI tool towards a particular kind of output, drawing on Mollick's characterisation of prompts as "programmes in prose". This brief conceptual anchor sets shared vocabulary for all subsequent prompting work. Encourage participants to treat prompting as a dialogue skill rather than a technical coding task.
steps.presentation:
## What is a prompt? A prompt is a **natural-language instruction that directs a GenAI tool to produce a particular kind of output**.
> "Prompts are basically programs in prose, and do not require any coding experience to write." [Mollick, 20.08.2023](https://www.oneusefulthing.org/p/now-is-the-time-for-grimoires)
> "Chatting is the new programming. [...] In essence, your chat prompt(s) are how you program the AI to do things for you. Instead of needing to write computer code, your written language is how you control the AI." [Liu, 04.2023](https://educational-innovation.sydney.edu.au/teaching@sydney/prompt-engineering-for-educators-making-generative-ai-work-for-you/#assessment)
steps.linksReferences:

| Category | Command | Function / Expected Action | Specific Benefit |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **✍️ Writing & Style** | `/STYLE-POLISH` | Syntactic smoothing. | Improves form without betraying the content. |
| | `/TEXT-SIMPLIFY` | Popularization (12-year-old level). | Makes dense concepts accessible. |
| | `/TONE-PRO` | Switch to corporate/neutral tone. | Professionalizes a draft. |
| | `/TONE-ENGAGING` | Switch to dynamic/emotional tone. | Increases marketing impact. |
| | `/FIX-GRAMMAR` | Strict spelling correction. | Contextual "Grammar Checker 2.0." |
| | `/TEXT-SHORTEN` | Condensation (-50%). | Synthesis for quick reading. |
| | `/TEXT-EXPAND` | Argued development. | Enriches points that are too brief. |
| | `/TITLE-GEN` | Generation of 10 titles. | Fights writer's block. |
| | `/HOOK-GEN` | Creation of hooks. | Optimizes reader attention. |
| | `/SYNONYM-LIST` | Search for lexical nuances. | Enriches vocabulary. |
| **🧠 Analysis & Synthesis** | `/SUM-BULLETS` | Bulleted list summary. | Visual structure of information. |

| | `/KEY-TAKEAWAYS` | Extraction of core ideas. | Memorization of essentials. |
| | `/SENTIMENT-ANALYSIS`| Tone analysis. | Understanding unspoken emotions. |

steps.title: Questioning prompt engineering: "nothing beats practice"
steps.objective: Challenges the idea of prompt engineering as a durable technical expertise, presenting evidence that AI systems are increasingly effective at inferring intent. The key reframe: rather than memorising frameworks, participants should cultivate a habit of iterative dialogue and critical evaluation of outputs. Introduce the core principles of effective prompting (clarity, context, iteration) that hold regardless of how models change.
steps.tasks: Learn prompting principles, understand dialogue vs command approach, grasp iteration and refinement as core practices
steps.presentation:
## Questioning prompt engineering: "nothing beats practice"
---

### Prompt engineering is likely a short-lived advantage
> "Being “good at prompting” is a temporary state of affairs. The current AI systems are already very good at figuring out your intent, and they are getting better. Prompting is not going to be that important for that much longer." [Mollick, 2023](https://www.oneusefulthing.org/p/a-guide-to-prompting-ai-for-what)

> "The great revolution of these AIs is their ease of access and use thanks to prompts. Having to call on a prompt engineer to effectively exploit generative AIs would result in a reduction in the number of users. The aim of providers will be to remove this barrier to entry and ensure that AIs are less reliant on 'very good' prompts to generate very good content." - Julia, Luc. 2025. *IA génératives, pas créatives - L'intelligence artificielle n'existe (toujours) pas*. Cherche Midi. (Translated)
---

### AI literacy is shifting from tool-specific prompting to human-centred communication
> "The progression is clear: **machines are meeting us where we are, not demanding we learn to speak their language**. Generative AI tools now explain how to use them while you're using them. They adapt to natural language, handle ambiguity, and provide real-time guidance.
> This represents a **fundamental shift in human-computer interaction**. For the first time in computing history, the interface barrier is essentially disappearing [...]. The prerequisite for telling a machine what to do is no longer technical expertise. It's simply **being able to communicate as a human being**.
> So, why are we rushing to create AI literacy curricula that focus on prompt engineering, understanding algorithms, and the technical specifications of specific AI tools? We're preparing students for a paradigm that's already becoming obsolete. [...]  [None of the required skills] are AI-specific skills. They're **human-centred capabilities** that remain valuable regardless of what technological interfaces emerge." ([Lodge, 2025](https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/why-ai-literacy-go-way-floppy-disk-jason-m-lodge-gg4yc))
---

### Stop chasing “the perfect prompt” — iterate with the AI.
> "The best way to use AI systems is not to craft the perfect prompt, but rather to use it interactively. Try asking for something. Then ask the AI to modify or adjust its output. Work with the AI, rather than trying to issue a single command that does everything you want. The more you experiment, the better off you are." [Ethan Mollick, 26.04,2023](https://www.oneusefulthing.org/p/a-guide-to-prompting-ai-for-what)

steps.title: Main prompting approaches
steps.objective: A brief overview of the current landscape of prompting approaches and general guidelines for effective prompt design (Tuomi, 2023; promptingguide.ai). Emphasise that no single framework is universally optimal and that context, task type, and the specific model all affect what works. Position this as orientation for the hands-on exploration that follows rather than a taxonomy to memorise.
steps.presentation:
## An evolving landscape, but some general guidelines
> "As the underlying language models are continuously changing, it is not clear that deep expertise can emerge on prompt engineering on these platforms. There are, however, some general guidelines for effective prompt design» [Tuomi, 2023](doi:10.2760/079734, JRC134308)
---

## Main prompting approaches

| Method | Description | Characteristics | Best Use Case |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Simple or naïve prompting**) | Relies on natural language and the model's ability to infer intent and context. | Flexible, conversational, but can be unpredictable for complex tasks. | Simple queries or creative brainstorming. |
  | **Structured Commands** (doesn't always work) | Uses explicit technical formatting (e.g., slash commands like `/NO-YAPPING`) to impose strict constraints. | Predictable, consistent, and treats the AI like a programming interface. | Systems requiring deterministic behaviour and high consistency. |
| **Conversational Prompting** | Builds context through multiple exchanges, refining instructions and providing examples incrementally. | Steering-oriented, iterative, and maintains a natural dialogue flow. | Nuanced tasks requiring refinement or detailed context. |

steps.title: Tokens and context windows
steps.objective: Concise explanation of the two technical concepts participants most frequently encounter in practice: tokens (the basic units of text processed by language models) and context windows (the maximum number of tokens a model can consider in a single interaction). These concepts directly affect how participants structure long prompts, upload documents, and manage multi-turn conversations in Copilot.
steps.presentation:
- **Token**: Smallest unit of text processed by language models.
- **Context Window**: Maximum tokens a model can consider at once.

steps.title: Zero-shot prompting (naïve prompting) and the power of inference
steps.objective: Demonstrates that modern GenAI systems can produce highly relevant responses from minimal, unstructured prompts by inferring professional context — particularly in specialist domains like educational inspection. Helps participants understand when simple prompting suffices and when more structured approaches become necessary (high-stakes, precision-sensitive, or document-heavy tasks).
steps.presentation:
## Simple or naïve prompting: The power of inference
- **Reading Between the Lines:** Modern Generative AI is remarkably adept at identifying the context of educational oversight without explicit instructions.
- **"Anything Goes":** Relying on the AI's internal reasoning to deduce intent, professional tone, and required standards.
- **Efficiency:** Ideal for quick drafts, summarising internal memos, or brainstorming initial inspection points.
---
## Need help? Let the AI guide you
- If a naïve prompt is too vague, use a **Meta-Prompt** to trigger the AI's requirements:
> "I want to [INSERT TASK]."

steps.title: Structured command: presentation
steps.objective: Introduces structured commands — categorised, named instruction types (e.g. summarise, classify, rewrite, extract) — as a way of making prompts more precise and reproducible. Note that command behaviour varies across models and should always be tested empirically. This is preparatory content for the hands-on exploration that follows immediately.

steps.title: Structured command: hands-on exploration
steps.objective: Participants try a selection of structured commands in Copilot, observing how different command types affect output. This exploratory activity (10 minutes) is designed to build intuition rather than mastery. Encourage participants to try commands relevant to their own inspection tasks and to note what works well and what produces unexpected results.
steps.presentation:
## Structured command: hands-on exploration
- Try some commands.

steps.title: Prompting frameworks and methods
steps.objective: Develop practical prompting skills from basic to advanced techniques
steps.tasks: Learn basic and advanced prompting techniques, practice crafting prompts for inspection scenarios, receive partner feedback, refine prompts, evaluate effectiveness
steps.presentation:
## Prompting frameworks and methods
- Prompting frameworks are structured, repeatable methods for constructing AI prompts.
- You will find online many frameworks and methods.

---
### Elements of a structured prompt
![](https://publish-01.obsidian.md/access/02eced38475abc30c65e3248f9ca8625/IMAGES/IA/Elements%20of%20a%20Good%20Prompt.png)
[source](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/education/blog/2024/06/five-quick-prompting-tips-to-get-more-from-your-ai-assistant/?msockid=1bcb37798fda68c2394624908eb66980) + [Unlock generative AI safely and responsibly — toolkit | Microsoft Learn](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/training/educator-center/instructor-materials/classroom-toolkit-unlock-generative-ai-safely-responsibly)

---
## IGEC context
| Prompt Element | Description | IGEC Example |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Persona** (role) | Ask the tool to take a specific role. | "Act as a senior IGEC expert with expertise in Portuguese administrative law." |
| **Objective** | Define exactly what you want the AI to do. | "Analyse this school's internal regulation document to identify any non-compliance with the current Legal Regime for Education." |
| **Audience** | Specify who the generated content is for. | "The analysis is for the Board of Directors of a public grouping of schools (Agrupamento de Escolas)." |
| **Context** | Provide the background information the tool needs. | "This is part of an extraordinary inspection following a complaint regarding student disciplinary procedures." |
| **Boundaries** | Set your own direction, style, and limitations. | "The response should be strictly technical, not exceeding two pages, and must cite specific Decree-Laws where applicable." |

steps.title: Prompting frameworks: Hands on exercices
steps.objective: Participants use the simple online prompt builder to construct prompts using a structured framework, then submit their prompts via the shared MS Form for group review. The activity bridges conceptual understanding and practice, and the collected prompts serve as raw material for the shared prompt library work in Day 3.
steps.presentation:
## Open the simple prompt builder
- [simple prompt builder](https://jourde.github.io/GenAI-training-IGEC/activities/simple-prompt-builder.html)
- Build a few prompts.
- Share the prompts via the [online MS Form](https://forms.office.com/e/cKkxgW98RH).

steps.title: In-context learning
steps.objective: Introduces few-shot and many-shot prompting: providing the model with one or more worked examples within the prompt to guide the style, format, or reasoning pattern of the output. Particularly useful for inspection-specific outputs (e.g. structured observation notes, standardised report sections) where consistency of format is important. Brief demonstration followed by a short participant practice.
steps.presentation:

### Few-shot prompting / Many-shot prompting -> Provide a language model with a small/large number of examples ("shots") in the prompt to guide its output and improve performance on specific tasks.

steps.title: Prompt-audit template(s)
steps.objective: Introduces meta-prompting as a quality-assurance technique: using GenAI itself to critique and improve a prompt before deployment. Presents two ready-to-use audit templates — simple (identify structural flaws) and advanced (evaluate methodological rigour). Encourage participants to use these as a professional habit before submitting high-stakes prompts in their inspection work.
steps.presentation:
## prompt-audit template(s)
Prompts to get prompt critique + revisions.
### simple
> "Identify structural flaws in the following prompt for generative AI and suggest modifications to resolve them. Here is the prompt:"
### advanced
> Evaluate the prompt for methodological flaws. Identify any sections that:
> 1. Assume capabilities LLMs do not have (such as stable internal scales, causal reasoning, self-verification, measurement, or non-textual inference),
> 2. push the model toward hallucination or unsupported quantitative output,
> 3. rely on false assumptions about how autoregressive LLMs generate text, and
> 4. structurally undermine reliability.
> For each issue, explain the underlying technical reason (e.g., token-by-token generation, lack of internal models, no grounding, no access to hidden states, stochastic sampling).
> Here is the prompt to evaluate:"

steps.title: RAG
steps.objective: Learn and practice RAG techniques with inspection documents

steps.presentation:
## RAG Model: The Core Process
![](https://images.ctfassets.net/j22is2dtoxu1/intercom-img-2ae66a9314952f17580c806a/2f928a1a8406fe5edf169ff82aaae357/s_2053BBCB2F039E3BBD53F077FDEF28F58E8A49B99632357DE8DCA7CAD68D0A10_1704327227253_Screenshot_2B2024-01-03_2Bat_2B4.13.36PM.png)
[image](https://help.openai.com/en/articles/8868588-retrieval-augmented-generation-rag-and-semantic-search-for-gpts)
.
- **User Query:** The user submits a prompt or question.
- **Vector Search:** An internal search engine uses an **embedding model** to query a database (typically a vector store).
- **Context Retrieval:** The most **relevant sources** are retrieved and passed to the Large Language Model (LLM).
- **Augmented Generation:** The LLM generates an informed response based on these sources and returns it to the user.

steps.title: The use of Markdown and JSON for structured documents
steps.objective: Explains why document format matters for RAG performance: structured content (using Markdown headings, lists, and tables, or JSON schemas) produces lighter prompts, more reliable retrieval, and more consistent outputs than unformatted prose. Participants learn to convert or format documents for AI processing — a skill that directly supports the prompt library and SPA development work in Day 3.
steps.tasks: Learn what RAG is and when to use it, understand optimisation strategies (Markdown, document structure, chunking), practice with Portuguese inspection documents, troubleshoot issues
steps.presentation:
## Optimising RAG with Structured Content
To improve the performance of a **Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)** system, the format of the retrieved data is just as important as the content itself. 
### 1. Why Structure Matters
* **Lighter Prompts:** Highly structured content requires fewer instructions (you don't need to explain how to read the data if the format is inherently logical).
* **Increased Accuracy:** LLMs are statistically better at extracting specific values from structured formats than from "wall-of-text" paragraphs.
* **Contextual Clarity:** Structured data allows the AI to immediately identify relationships between entities (e.g., a "Name" linked to a "Participant ID").

### 2. Preferred Text-Based Formats
For RAG, two formats stand out as the industry standards:
#### **Markdown (.md)**
* **Best for:** Hierarchical documents, manuals, and articles.
* **Why:** It uses simple headers (`#`, `##`) and tables that LLMs understand perfectly. It preserves document structure without the overhead of heavy code.
> [What is Markdown? Getting started](https://www.markdownguide.org/getting-started/)
#### **JSON (.json)**
* **Best for:** Technical data, specifications, and database records.
* **Why:** It provides a strict **Key-Value** pair relationship. This is ideal for when you need the GenAI to perform specific lookups or comparisons (e.g., "Find the dimensions of Part X").

### 3. The Result
By providing structured snippets, you can **omit complex parameters** or lengthy explanations in your system prompt. The AI treats the structure as the roadmap, leading to faster processing and more reliable outputs.

---
## Why Markdown (MD) is Superior for RAG Pipelines

Converting documents from layout-heavy formats (PDF, Word) into **Markdown (MD)** is a strategic optimisation for Retrieval-Augmented Generation. While PDFs are designed for human eyes, Markdown is built for machine readability and structural clarity.

### 1. Structural Preservation (Semantic Hierarchy)
* **Headers as Anchors:** Markdown uses simple syntax (`#`, `##`, `###`) to denote hierarchy. This allows the RAG system to understand which "chunk" belongs to which section, preserving the relationship between a subheading and its content.
* **Tables and Lists:** In a PDF, a table is often just a collection of floating text. In Markdown, tables are structured as rows and columns, allowing the LLM to perform accurate data lookups (e.g., matching a price to a specific part number).

### 2. Token Efficiency & Noise Reduction
* **Stripping Metadata:** PDF and Word files contain hidden formatting code, font data, and page coordinates. Converting to MD removes this "noise," ensuring that every token sent to the LLM is actual, useful information.
* **Cleaner Chunking:** It is much easier to split a document logically at a Markdown header than at an arbitrary page break, which often cuts sentences or context in half.

### 3. Improved Retrieval Accuracy
* **Better Embeddings:** When text is clean and logically ordered, the **Embedding Model** creates more accurate mathematical vectors. This leads to higher "hit rates" during the search phase—meaning the AI finds the correct answer more consistently.
* **Contextual Weight:** Markdown makes it easier for the system to keep the "parent" context (like a chapter title) attached to a small snippet of text, giving the LLM the full picture even if it only sees one paragraph.

### 4. LLM "Native" Language
Most Large Language Models are trained extensively on web data, documentation, and code repositories. Consequently, **Markdown is the format LLMs understand most naturally**, leading to faster processing and more coherent reasoning.

### Summary of Benefits

| Feature | PDF / Word | Markdown (MD) |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Structure** | Visual/Layout based | Logical/Semantic |
| **Noise** | High (Metadata/Fonts) | Low (Pure Text) |
| **Searchability** | Fragmented | Integrated |
| **LLM Parsing** | Difficult/Variable | Highly Reliable |

---
## How to convert a document into MD or JSON?
- Many options...

moments.title: Creating shared prompt libraries for organisational consistency
moments.description: This 90-minute morning moment launches Day 3's collective work by establishing the rationale and design principles for a shared organisational prompt library. It moves from ideation (why and how to share prompts) through a break to a hands-on project session in which participants collaboratively design the structure of a prompt database and an associated collection form.

steps.title: Ideation: Why Shared Prompt Libraries Matter (Consistency, QA, Onboarding)
steps.objective: The Power of Shared Libraries: Why and How?
steps.presentation:
## Shared libraries of prompts
---
### Why?
A shared prompt library makes expert reasoning repeatable, auditable, and improvable across a team. It is useful when work is (a) high-variance, (b) compliance-sensitive, and (c) dependent on tacit expertise.

The output of this session informs the afternoon SPA development.

moments.title: 13:30-17:00 - Building and Implementing the Prompt Generator
moments.description: The afternoon session uses vibe-coding (iterative AI-assisted front-end development) to build and refine a single-page web application (SPA) that operationalises the morning's prompt library design. Moving from a brief introduction and a worked example through hands-on exercises to a trainer-led live build and group refinements, participants experience the full cycle of AI-assisted development and end the day with a working prototype and a deployment roadmap.

steps.title: What is vibe-coding?
steps.objective: A brief (5-minute) conceptual introduction to vibe-coding: the practice of directing AI to write, modify, and debug code through natural-language prompts in an iterative loop. Positions the technique as an accessible way for non-developers to build functional digital tools, directly relevant to the prompt generator the group will build today. Emphasise that the critical skill is clear specification, not coding knowledge.
steps.presentation: ## What is vibe-coding?

steps.title: Vibe coding example: the PT laboratory checklist
steps.objective: The trainer walks through a worked vibe-coding example drawn from Day 2 (the Portuguese laboratory checklist), demonstrating the iterative prompt–review–refine cycle and highlighting the kinds of instructions that produce reliable versus unreliable results. Note common pitfalls: ambiguous specifications, accumulated errors across iterations, and the importance of reviewing every output before accepting it.
steps.presentation: ## Vibe coding example: the PT laboratory checklist (from DAY 2)

The trainer circulates to support and to identify participants who may need additional scaffolding.

Positions the SPA as the practical output of the day and frames the afternoon build session that follows.

steps.title: What are Single Page Application (SPA)? Examples
steps.objective: A concise (5-minute) explanation of what SPAs are — web applications that run entirely in the browser without page reloads — illustrated with accessible examples. The goal is to give participants enough conceptual clarity to understand what they are building and to make informed decisions about its scope and limitations, not to teach front-end development.

steps.objective:
## Upgrade the single prompt builder
- Download the [HTML file](https://github.com/jourde/GenAI-training-IGEC/blob/main/activities/simple-prompt-builder.html)
- Prompt the app upgrade iteratively, based on the pattern matrix.
---

## GenAI prompt to produce the app (copy/paste)

```
# Role: You are a senior front-end engineer.

# Context:
- You are developing a single-page local web app for IGEC professionals to help them consistently generate prompts.
- The app operationalises repeatable prompt decisions into dropdowns, checkboxes, and free-text boxes.

# Inputs:
I will paste workshop results:
- A Pattern Matrix and/or completed Standard Pattern Templates. Do not invent patterns or options not implied by the provided data.
- A Single Prompt Builder HTML file to serve as the app base.

# Constraints:
- Use British English for UI labels.
- Accessibility: **WCAG 2.1 Compliance**.

# Output format:
1) Provide the revised HTML file.
2) Explain the main modifications
```

steps.title: Group refinements of the app
steps.objective:
Assign refinement slices (trainer chooses 1 per group) — 1 min

Pick from:

1. **Prompt quality enforcement**: remove duplication; guarantee order; ensure hard rules cannot be accidentally removed.
    
2. **Pattern editing UX**: add “Add/remove section” and “Add/remove verb row” (bounded to 3–5).
    
3. **Export/import robustness**: validate JSON schema; show friendly error messages.
    
4. **LocalStorage and versioning**: store last saved timestamp; allow “Restore previous”.
    
5. **Accessibility improvements**: fieldset/legend, aria-live for copy status, keyboard shortcuts.
    

## B2. Vibe-coding patch prompt (each group uses) — 10–11 min

```text
You are improving a single-file local HTML app (no external libraries).

Goal:
Implement the following refinement slice: [PASTE ASSIGNED SLICE]

Constraints:
- Keep everything in one `index.html` file.
- Preserve the existing data model (DATA + state).
- Do not break: pattern selection, live prompt preview, copy/export/import, localStorage.
- UI labels in British English.

Return:
- The full updated `index.html`.

Here is the current file:
[PASTE index.html]
```

The output is a concrete, agreed roadmap that participants carry back to their institution.
